section.title: TAN-class-2 elements, attributes, and patterns summarized

section.para: The element align declares one or more groups of words or divs that should be aligned with each other. If in a TAN-A-tok file, <align> governs <tok>s (words); in TAN-A-div files, <div-ref> (divs and segments)

In TAN-A-tok files, <align> specifies that all the tokens invoked for one source collectively align with the tokens in the other. This version of <align> allows @cert, @bitext-relation, and @reuse-type, in addition to the editorial stamp.

In TAN-A-div files, <align> specifies that every group of divs or segments (defined by a child <div-ref>) should be aligned with every other group in the alingment. This alignment is to be taken as adding to any default, automatic alignment. This version of <align> allows @strength, @exclusive, and @distribute, which affect the default behavior of <align>. For more see

important.para: A defective reference is a value of @ref that corresponds to a <div> in some but not all sources in a work. If a defective reference is used, a warning will be reported, identifying the sources that lack the appropriate <div>.

caution.para: The <div-ref>s in an <align> that does not have @exclusive set to true may take only one value for @src.
A <tok> may not duplicate any sibling <tok>.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> ......... <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="1" pos="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="1" pos="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="1" pos="2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="1" pos="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="1" pos="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="1" pos="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="1" pos="4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="1" pos="4"/> </align> <align> ......... </align> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The element group-type defines types of classes, used primarily to explain the nature of <group>s.
The element rename indicates the name of a <div> @n or @type that should be changed, and the name to which it should be changed.
To change Roman numerals or letter numeration to Arabic numerals use this syntax:

caution.para: @old and @new may not share the same value
No value of @new or @old may appear more than once for a given div type in a given source.
If @new or @old refers to an n type (#1, #a, #i) then the other must as well.
Every value of @old must appear for a given div type in a given source.
An instruction to convert from letter or Roman numerals requires that the values of @n to be predominantly of that type.

example.programlisting: <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> </rename-div-ns>
<declarations> ......... <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> </declarations>

section.para: The element rename-div-ns provisionally reassigns @n values for one or more sources and one or more div types. Renaming applies only to the current file.
This element is especially useful for converting Roman numerals or letter numerals into Arabic numerals. See <rename> for syntax.

This feature is strictly speaking a convenience, not a necessity. All TAN-compliant preprocessors are required to automatically detect Roman and alphabetic numbering systems and treat them as Arabic numerals.

It is also useful for div types that use descriptive names for @n (such as books of the Bible), particularly for reconciling those names with a system that prevails or is preferred (e.g., "mt" to "Matt").

Note for TAN-A-div users: Although this element can reconcile simple differences, it should not be used for more complex inconsistencies that affect alignment, best handled in the <body> of a TAN-A-div file.

caution.para: Every div type reference must be valid in every source

example.programlisting: <declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> </rename-div-ns> <comment when="2016-02-22-05:00" who="park">The following is equivalent to @which = 'letters'</comment> ......... </declarations>

<declarations> ......... <token-definition src="eng ger" which="letters and punctuation"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> </declarations>

section.para: The element suppress-div-types marks div types in a source that should be suppressed in references. Suppressions occur shallowly. That is, it does not suppress any descendants of that div type. But if the suppression applies to a leaf div, that div and its text is effectively suppressed.
Any suppression of a div type must preserve the Leaf Div Uniqueness Rule (LDUR). See
This element will be used seldomly, for cases where a source has a div type that is dispensable in text references.

caution.para: Every div type reference must be valid in every source

example.programlisting: <declarations> <suppress-div-types src="fra" div-type-ref="sec"/> </declarations>

<declarations> <suppress-div-types src="eng-1790" div-type-ref="poem"/> <comment when="2016-02-22-05:00" who="park">The following token definition treats the following as words: sequences of letters, any individual character that is neither a letter nor a space (i.e., punctuation).</comment> ......... </declarations>

section.para: The element tok identifies one or more words or word fragments. Used by class 2 files to make assertions about specific words.

caution.para: Every token must be locatable in every cited ref in every source.
<tok> must reference a leaf <div>.
No source may be split more than once in the same place.
Splits may not be made at the first token in a div.
A <tok> may not duplicate any sibling <tok>.
Any ana with an @xml:id must point to no more than one token.

example.programlisting: <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="fra" ref="1 1" pos="3"/> </split-leaf-div-at>
<split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="eng-us" ref="2" pos="last-3"/> </split-leaf-div-at>
<body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="1" pos="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="1" pos="1"/> </align> ......... </body>

section.para: The attribute chars list of one or more characters, specified through Arabic numerals, the keyword 'last' or 'last-X' (where X is a valid number), joined with commas or hyphens.

caution.para: Sequences may not include values less than 1.
Sequences may not include values greater than the maximum allowed.
Sequences may not include ranges that go from a larger value to a smaller, e.g., 4 - 2.

example.programlisting: <ana> <tok ref="1 1 1 2" val="τοὔνομα" chars="1 - 2"/> <lm> ......... </lm> </ana>

section.para: The attribute class supplies a value intended to optimize searching for <tok>s, especially in applications that use XSLT and XPath key functions.

The attribute cont indicates whether the current element is continued by the next one and to be treated as a single one. Value must be 1 or true, implied by the very presence of the attribute. If you wish to decare it to be false, delete the attribute altogether.

This feature is useful in <tok> for rejoining the portion of a word split across two <div>s, or for uniting into a single linguistic token multiple tokens separated by the tokenization process, e.g., "pom pom".
This feature is useful in <div-ref> for creating groups of references that cannot be expressed in a single <div-ref>

caution.para: Any element taking @cont must be followed by at least one sibling of the same type.

section.para: The attribute div-type-ref is used by class-2 files to point to one or more <div-type>s in class-1 files. Permits multiple values separated by spaces.

caution.para: Every div type reference must be valid in every source

example.programlisting: <declarations> <suppress-div-types src="fra" div-type-ref="sec"/> </declarations>

<TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ring01-TAN-A-ring02"> <head> ......... <declarations> <suppress-div-types src="eng-1790" div-type-ref="poem"/> <comment when="2016-02-22-05:00" who="park">The following token definition treats the following as words: sequences of letters, any individual character that is neither a letter nor a space (i.e., punctuation).</comment> ......... </declarations> ......... </head> <body> ......... <equate-div-types> <div-type-ref src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"/> <div-type-ref src="eng-uk" div-type-ref="line"/> </equate-div-types> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>

section.para: The attribute new provides the new name for an @n or @type that is to be renamed

caution.para: @old and @new may not share the same value
No value of @new or @old may appear more than once for a given div type in a given source.
If @new or @old refers to an n type (#1, #a, #i) then the other must as well.
Every value of @old must appear for a given div type in a given source.
An instruction to convert from letter or Roman numerals requires that the values of @n to be predominantly of that type.

example.programlisting: <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> </rename-div-ns>
<declarations> ......... <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> </declarations>

section.para: The attribute old provides the name of an @n or @type in a source to be renamed

caution.para: @old and @new may not share the same value
No value of @new or @old may appear more than once for a given div type in a given source.
If @new or @old refers to an n type (#1, #a, #i) then the other must as well.
Every value of @old must appear for a given div type in a given source.
An instruction to convert from letter or Roman numerals requires that the values of @n to be predominantly of that type.

example.programlisting: <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> </rename-div-ns>
<declarations> ......... <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> </declarations>

section.para: The attribute pos lists one or more items, specified through Arabic numerals and the keyword 'last' or 'last-X' (where X is a valid number), joined with commas or hyphens.
Any hyphen used as a range should be preceded and followed by at least one space character.

caution.para: Sequences may not include values less than 1.
Sequences may not include values greater than the maximum allowed.
Sequences may not include ranges that go from a larger value to a smaller, e.g., 4 - 2.

example.programlisting: <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="fra" ref="1 1" pos="3"/> </split-leaf-div-at>
<split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="eng-us" ref="2" pos="last-3"/> </split-leaf-div-at>
<body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="1" pos="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="1" pos="1"/> </align> ......... </body>

section.para: The attribute ref lists references to one or more <div>s. It consists of one or more atomic references joined with commas or hyphens. An atomic reference is a string value that points to a single <div>. In most cases (i.e., when @distribute is not in force), multiple atomic references are treated collectively, as a single reference to a complex passage, not as multiple references to individual passages.
Any hyphen used as a range should be preceded and followed by at least one space character.

caution.para: Every @ref must be found in every source mentioned by @src.
If @ref points to a leaf div, it must be unique.

important.para: A defective reference is a value of @ref that corresponds to a <div> in some but not all sources in a work. If a defective reference is used, a warning will be reported, identifying the sources that lack the appropriate <div>.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a-div"> ......... <body> <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="fra" ref="1 1" pos="3"/> </split-leaf-div-at> <realign> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1" seg="2"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="1 1 1 - 1 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1 - 1 3"/> </realign> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>

section.para: The attribute src refers to the ID of one or more <source>s

caution.para: Every idref in an attribute must point to the @xml:id value of the appropriate corresponding element.
All idrefs in an attribute must be unique.
The <div-ref>s in an <align> that does not have @exclusive set to true may take only one value for @src.
@src in <anchor-div-ref> may take no more than one value.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a-div"> <head> ......... <declarations> <suppress-div-types src="fra" div-type-ref="sec"/> </declarations> ......... </head> <body> <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="fra" ref="1 1" pos="3"/> </split-leaf-div-at> <realign> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1" seg="2"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="1 1 1 - 1 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1 - 1 3"/> </realign> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>

section.para: The attribute val specifies a particular word token by means of its string value. Permits regular expressions. Therefore a request for help should consist of a space before or after a question mark.

caution.para: Attributes that take a regular expression must use escape sequences recognized by XML schema or TAN escape extensions (\k{}). See http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#regexs for details.
@val must wholly match a token in the target.

important.para: A @val set to '.+', a regular expression that matches any string, is equivalent to the omission of @valA @val set to '.+', a regular expression that matches any string, is equivalent to the omission of @val

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> ......... <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> ......... <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="2" val="A"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="2" val="A"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="2" val="pocket"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="2" val="pocket"/> </align> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.title: TAN-A-div elements, attributes, and patterns summarized

section.para: The element anchor-div-ref defines a <div> to which other <div>s in other versions of the same work should be realigned (via <div-ref>s that follow). The first child of a <realign>, it is constructed exactly like <div-ref>, except that the mandatory @src may point only to a single source.
<anchor-div-ref> is always followed by one or more <div-ref>s.

If <anchor-div-ref> points to only one reference (i.e., @src, @ref, and @seg [if present] each have only one value) then however many references are made in subsequent <div-ref>s, they will all be realigned to that one anchor reference.
But if <anchor-div-ref> has more than one reference, then distribution is in effect. Every nth reference will be the anchor for the nth reference in subsequent <div-ref>s (grouped by source).

caution.para: @src in <anchor-div-ref> may take no more than one value.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a-div"> ......... <body> ......... <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="1 1 1 - 1 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1 - 1 3"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="3 1 1 - 3 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="3 1 - 3 3"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="5 1 1 - 5 1 4"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="5 1 - 5 4"/> </realign> <realign> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="5 1 5 - 5 1 7"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="5 5"/> </realign> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>

section.para: The element div-ref collects one or more <div>s (or segments of <div>s) in one or more sources

In most cases, the texts pointed to in <div-ref> will be treated as a collective set. If passage A is found three times in X, Y, and Z, then in an <align> four different <div-ref>s should be used. But if A is found once, spanning X, Y, and Z, then the last three should be gathered in a single <div-ref>, or, optionally, in a <div-ref> with a @cont.

important.para: A defective reference is a value of @ref that corresponds to a <div> in some but not all sources in a work. If a defective reference is used, a warning will be reported, identifying the sources that lack the appropriate <div>.

caution.para: The <div-ref>s in an <align> that does not have @exclusive set to true may take only one value for @src.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a-div"> ......... <body> ......... <realign> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1" seg="2"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="1 1 1 - 1 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1 - 1 3"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="3 1 1 - 3 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="3 1 - 3 3"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="5 1 1 - 5 1 4"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="5 1 - 5 4"/> </realign> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>

section.para: The element div-type-ref points to a <div-type> in one or more sources, using the @xml:id assigned by the source to that div type.

caution.para: Every div type reference must be valid in every source

example.programlisting: <body> ......... <equate-div-types> <div-type-ref src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"/> <div-type-ref src="eng-uk" div-type-ref="line"/> </equate-div-types> ......... </body>

section.para: The element equate-div-types declares an ad hoc equivalence between div types that are not defined by their sources as being identical.

Any two <div-type>s that share at least one <IRI> value will be treated as equivalent; those that do not will be treated as different div types. <equate-div-types> permits you to make an ad hoc equivalence between one or more <div-type-ref>s.

<equate-div-types> are assumed to be greedy and transitive. If this element is used to equate div type X with type Y, then any div type in any source identical to X's or Y's IRI values will treated as identical.
This element does not imply that the two types of division are, in reality, one and the same. It merely states that, for the purposes of this alignment, they should be treated as equivalent.

caution.para: Items that share IRI values should not be equated.
Every div type reference must be valid in every source

example.programlisting: <body> <equate-works src="eng-uk ger"/> <equate-div-types> <div-type-ref src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"/> <div-type-ref src="eng-uk" div-type-ref="line"/> </equate-div-types> <split-leaf-div-at> ......... </split-leaf-div-at> ......... </body>

section.para: The element equate-works declares an ad hoc equivalence between works that are not defined by their sources as being identical.

Any two <work>s that share at least one <IRI> value will be treated as equivalent; those that do not will be treated as different div types. <equate-works> permits you to make an ad hoc equivalence between one or more <work>s.

<equate-div-types> are assumed to be greedy and transitive. If this element is used to equate work X with type Y, then any any source with a work identical to X's or Y's IRI values will treated as identical. If work X of source A is stated to be equivalent to work Y of source B, then any work in any source identical to X will be identical to any work in any source identical to Y. So to equate two works, each with multiple members, you need declare the equivalence between only one member of each work, not all of them.
This element does not imply that the two works are, in reality, one and the same. It merely states that, for the purposes of this alignment, they should be treated as equivalent.

caution.para: Items that share IRI values should not be equated.

example.programlisting: <body> <equate-works src="eng-uk ger"/> <equate-div-types> ......... </equate-div-types> ......... </body>

section.para: The element realign corrects wrongly aligned divisions and segments in versions of the same work. This element (1) exempts any divs or segments referred to in children <div-ref>s from their default alignments and (2) realigns them together as a group. Realignments have two types.

An UNANCHORED realigment is useful for divisions that need to be removed from any automatic alignment. It consists solely of one or more <div-ref>s. The effect is (1) to sever each referenced <div> from any automatic alignment and (2) to realign each source's nth reference (div or segment) with the nth reference in every other other source, if any, invoked in the <realign>. If only one source is invoked in a <realign>, only the first effect takes place: the references are effectively severed from any automatic alignment with any other version for that source. Realignment is inherited, affecting not only the specified <div>s but their descendants too.

An ANCHORED realignment is useful for making sure a minority of misplaced <div>s align with the majority. It begins with a single <anchor-div-ref> as the first child of <realign>, then one or more <div-ref>s. The effect is (1) to sever each referenced <div> from any automatic alignment and (2) to realign each source's nth reference (div or segment) with the nth reference in the anchor. If <anchor-div-ref> points to only one reference then all subsequent <div-ref>s will be tethered collectively to that one anchor reference.

Unanchored <realign>s effectively sever every <div-ref> from any automatic alignment. But anchored ones do not sever automatic alignment; they merely shift it to the anchor. This method is helpful for synchronizing a few sources with the reference system followed by the majority.

Because of the distributive nature of the realignment, every value of @ref that involves a hyphen must have siblings on the left and right side of the hyphen (i.e., ref="bk.1 - bk.2:ch.1" would be invalid).
This element is source-specific and not subject to any transitive properties. The assertions apply only to the specific sources that are cited.
If @seg is used, every @ref must point to a leaf <div>, and @seg must point to a valid segment defined by <split-leaf-div-at>.
For both anchored and unanchored alignments alike, the order of <div-ref>s is immaterial.

caution.para: A <div> may appear in a <realign> no more than once (whether <anchor-div-ref> or <div-ref>).

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a-div"> ......... <body> <split-leaf-div-at> ......... </split-leaf-div-at> <realign> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1" seg="2"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="1 1 1 - 1 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1 - 1 3"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="3 1 1 - 3 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="3 1 - 3 3"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="5 1 1 - 5 1 4"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="5 1 - 5 4"/> </realign> <realign> ......... </realign> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>

section.para: The element split-leaf-div-at creates ad hoc splits in leaf <div>s, to facilitate alignments and realignments of textual units smaller than leaf <div>s. Any leaf div may be split as many times as there are token, as defined by <tokenization>s.
Each split creates a segment, a textual subdivision of leaf <div>s introduced by the TAN-A-div file.

caution.para: Splits may be made only at leaf divs.
No source may be split more than once in the same place.
Splits may not be made at the first token in a div.

example.programlisting: <body> <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="fra" ref="1 1" pos="3"/> </split-leaf-div-at> <realign> ......... </realign> ......... </body>
<body> ......... <equate-div-types> ......... </equate-div-types> <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="eng-us" ref="2" pos="last-3"/> </split-leaf-div-at> <realign> ......... </realign> </body>

section.para: The element TAN-A-div specifies that the file is a div-based TAN alignment file. Root element.

important.para: Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a-div"> <head> ......... </head> <body> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>
<TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ring01-TAN-A-ring02"> <head> ......... </head> <body> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>

section.para: The element topic declares one or more topics, to be used in conjunction with @topic under <align> to associate alignments with specific topics instead of verbatim parallels.
The attribute distribute indicates whether values should be matched one-to-one, or grouped.
If this attribute is not present (= default / false()), then each set of references in a single <div-ref> will be treated as a set and aligned against every other <div-ref> set.

If @distribute is present (= true()), then every nth ref in every set (defined by a single <div-ref>, taking into account any continuations defined by @cont) will be aligned with the nth ref in every other set. Therefore the number of references derived from @refs must be identical.

If @distribute is true() then any ranges in @ref will be resolved shallowly, e.g., ref="2 b - 4" would be resolved something like ("2 b", "2 c", "3", "4"), even if there are further subdivisions of "3" and "4".
Value must be 1 or true, implied by the very presence of the attribute. If you wish to decare it to be false, delete the attribute altogether.

caution.para: Distribution must be applied to groups of equal size.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a-div"> ......... <body> ......... <realign> ......... </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="1 1 1 - 1 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1 - 1 3"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="3 1 1 - 3 1 3"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="3 1 - 3 3"/> </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="5 1 1 - 5 1 4"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="5 1 - 5 4"/> </realign> <realign> ......... </realign> <realign> ......... </realign> <realign distribute="1"> <anchor-div-ref src="grc" ref="5 2 3 - 5 2 5"/> <div-ref src="fra" ref="5 7 - 5 9"/> </realign> <realign> ......... </realign> ......... </body> </TAN-A-div>

section.para: The attribute exclusive indicates whether an alignment should be treated as non-transitive or transitive. If there is no @exclusive, then if X is aligned with Y, then anything that aligns with X will align with anything that aligns with Y. If @exclusive is present then the alignment holds only between the specified references. The latter is useful, e.g., for specifying cases where one version of a work uniquely quotes from another. Value must be 1 or true, implied by the very presence of the attribute. If you wish to decare it to be false, delete the attribute altogether.
The attribute seg picks specific segments in a leaf div (and only to leaf divs). There must be an appropriate number of splits declared for those leaf divs in <split-leaf-div-at>.

caution.para: @seg may not be applied to any element that is not a leaf div
Sequences may not include values less than 1.
Sequences may not include values greater than the maximum allowed.
Sequences may not include ranges that go from a larger value to a smaller, e.g., 4 - 2.

example.programlisting: <realign> <div-ref src="fra" ref="1 1" seg="2"/> </realign>

section.para: The attribute strength tempers the strength of an alignment. Suitable for alignments you would wish to differentiate, such as verbatim parallels from indirect references. This attribute does not imply doubt, uncertainty, or the reason for strengthening or weakening the alignment. If you need to specify exactly what concept of text reuse attaches to an alignment, you should use TAN-A-tok and <tok> with @reuse-type and @cert.

This attribute takes an arbitrary rational decimal number from 0 to 1 indicating how strong the alignment should be. No specific meaning is to be assigned to this attribute. Interpretation of these values is processor-dependent.

The attribute topic points to one or more topics to which an alignment should be associated. If this attribute is not present, it is assumed that the alignment links different versions of roughly the same text.
TAN does not stipluate what can be inferred via @topic. If ref A is aligned with B via topic x, and B with C via topic y, no guarantee is made as to what relationship A has to C.

section.title: TAN-A-tok elements, attributes, and patterns summarized

section.para: The element bitext-relation identifies how the text on one text-bearing object relates to that on another by specifying a relationship, e.g., B is a direct copy of A, B and A descent from a commont parent, etc. See for theoretical background.

In most cases, there will be need for only one of these elements. But multiple values may be helpful for cases where a bitext has a complex history, for example, a textual object that was created over time, and in different phases.
This element should not be used to describe any activities (e.g., translation, copying), reserved for <reuse-type>.

example.programlisting: <declarations> <bitext-relation xml:id="B-descends-from-A"> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:bitext-relation:a/x+/b</IRI> <name>B descends directly from A, unknown number of intermediaries</name> <desc>The 1987 versions is hypothesized to descend somehow from the 1881 version, mainly for the sake of illustration.</desc> </bitext-relation> <reuse-type xml:id="adaptation"> ......... </reuse-type> ......... </declarations>

<declarations> <bitext-relation xml:id="unclear"> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki@gmail.com,2014:bitext-relation:unclear</IRI> <name>The German and English versions bear some relationship, but what exactly is unclear.</name> </bitext-relation> <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> ......... </declarations>

<declarations> <bitext-relation xml:id="unclear"> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki@gmail.com,2014:bitext-relation:unclear</IRI> <name>The German and English versions bear some relationship, but what exactly is unclear.</name> </bitext-relation> <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> ......... </declarations>

section.para: The element reuse-type identifies a category of text reuse (e.g., translation, mistranslation, paraphrase, ridicule). See for theoretical background.

example.programlisting: <declarations> <bitext-relation xml:id="B-descends-from-A"> ......... </bitext-relation> <reuse-type xml:id="adaptation"> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:reuse-type:adaptation:general</IRI> <name>general adaptation</name> </reuse-type> <token-definition src="ring1881 ring1987" which="letters"/> </declarations>

<declarations> <bitext-relation xml:id="unclear"> ......... </bitext-relation> <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki@gmail.com,2014:reuse-type:correlation-general</IRI> <name>Texts are generally correlated, but without specifying the relation</name> </reuse-type> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> ......... </rename-div-ns> ......... </declarations>

<declarations> <bitext-relation xml:id="unclear"> ......... </bitext-relation> <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki@gmail.com,2014:reuse-type:correlation-general</IRI> <name>Texts are generally correlated, but without specifying the relation</name> </reuse-type> <token-definition src="eng ger" which="letters and punctuation"/> ......... </declarations>

section.para: The element TAN-A-tok specifies that the file is a token-based TAN alignment file. Root element.

important.para: Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <head> ......... </head> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03"> <head> ......... </head> <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03:alt"> <head> ......... </head> <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The attribute bitext-relation points to one or more <bitext-relation> @xml:id values that qualify the type of relation that holds. Multiple values assume inclusive or (A or B or A and B)

caution.para: Every idref in an attribute must point to the @xml:id value of the appropriate corresponding element.
All idrefs in an attribute must be unique.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <head> ......... </head> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03"> <head> ......... </head> <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03:alt"> <head> ......... </head> <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The attribute reuse-type points to one or more <reuse-type> @xml:id values that qualify the type of textual reuse that holds. Multiple values assume inclusive or (A or B or A and B)

caution.para: Every idref in an attribute must point to the @xml:id value of the appropriate corresponding element.
All idrefs in an attribute must be unique.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <head> ......... </head> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03"> <head> ......... </head> <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03:alt"> <head> ......... </head> <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> <align> ......... </align> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.title: TAN-LM elements, attributes, and patterns summarized
section.para: No attributes or elements are defined for TAN-LM.

section.title: TAN-class-3 elements, attributes, and patterns summarized
section.para: No attributes or elements are defined for TAN-class-3.

section.title: TAN-key elements, attributes, and patterns summarized

section.para: The element item names an item that is being described. The item is assumed to be a species of the type of thing discussed by the TAN element that is affected.

caution.para: @affects-element must include only names of TAN elements that accept @which
Every item in a reserved TAN-key must have at least one IRI with a tag URN in the TAN namespace

example.programlisting: <TAN-key TAN-version="1 dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-key:bitext-relation"> ......... <body in-progress="true" affects-element="bitext-relation"> <item> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:bitext-relation:unclear</IRI> <name>unclear</name> <name>unclear relation</name> ......... </item> <item> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:bitext-relation:a/b|b/a</IRI> <name>a/b|b/a</name> <desc>direct unmediated descent, unknown direction</desc> </item> <item> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:bitext-relation:a/b</IRI> <name>a/b</name> <desc>direct unmediated descent, B descends from A</desc> </item> <item> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:bitext-relation:b/a</IRI> <name>b/a</name> <desc>direct unmediated descent, A descends from B</desc> </item> <item> ......... </item> ......... </body> </TAN-key>

section.para: The element TAN-key specifies that the TAN file makes assertions subject a conceptual work. Root element.

important.para: Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.

example.programlisting: <TAN-key TAN-version="1 dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-key:bitext-relation"> <head> ......... </head> <body in-progress="true" affects-element="bitext-relation"> ......... </body> </TAN-key>
<TAN-key TAN-version="1 dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-key:div-types"> <head> ......... </head> <body in-progress="false" affects-element="div-type"> ......... </body> </TAN-key>
<TAN-key TAN-version="1 dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-key:features"> <head> ......... </head> <body in-progress="false" affects-element="feature"> ......... </body> </TAN-key>
<TAN-key TAN-version="1 dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-key:group-types"> <head> ......... </head> <body in-progress="false" affects-element="group-type"> ......... </body> </TAN-key>

section.title: TAN-mor elements, attributes, and patterns summarized

section.para: The element assert names a pattern that, if found to be false in any <m> in a dependent TAN-LM file, will return the enclosed message upon validation of the dependent file, along with an error or warning. Modeled loosely on Schematron <report>.

caution.para: @feature-test and @context must point to one or more feature @codes or @xml:ids a space or +

section.para: The element category creates a set of features that share a common grammatical trait such as gender, number, etc.

The element feature names, through its IRI + name pattern, a grammatical feature or concept (e.g., plural, subjunctive, 1st person) that characterizes a language. In the context of <feature> a @code is always included. The first <feature> of a <category> never has @code, and refers to the grammatical feature that characterizes the category.

caution.para: Every <feature> inclusion must support every language that has been declared.

example.programlisting: <TAN-mor TAN-version="1" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-r-mor:eng:penn"> ......... <body> <for-lang>eng</for-lang> <feature code="''"> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:morphology:option:quotation-mark-closing</IRI> <name>closing quotation mark</name> <desc>Examples: ' ''</desc> </feature> <feature code="--"> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Dash</IRI> <name>dash</name> <desc>Examples: --</desc> </feature> <feature code="$"> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Dollar_sign</IRI> <name>dollar</name> <desc>Examples: $ -$ --$ A$ C$ HK$ M$ NZ$ S$ U.S.$ US$</desc> </feature> <feature code="["> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:morphology:option:bracket-opening</IRI> <name>opening bracket</name> <desc>Examples: ( [ {</desc> </feature> <feature code="]"> ......... </feature> ......... </body> </TAN-mor>

section.para: The element report names a pattern that, if found to be true in any <m> in a dependent TAN-LM file, will return the enclosed message upon validation of the dependent file, along with an error or warning. Modeled loosely on Schematron <report>.

caution.para: @feature-test and @context must point to one or more feature @codes or @xml:ids a space or +

section.para: The element TAN-mor specifies that the TAN file contains definitions for the parts of speech for a language, the codes for those parts, and the rules for combining them. Root element.

important.para: Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.

example.programlisting: <TAN-mor TAN-version="1" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-r-mor:eng:penn"> <head> ......... </head> <body> ......... </body> </TAN-mor>

section.para: The attribute code contains a string that can be used as an alternative code for a <feature>.

caution.para: Codes for (@xml:id or @code) features must be case-indifferently unique within a given category.

example.programlisting: <TAN-mor TAN-version="1" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-r-mor:eng:penn"> ......... <body> <for-lang>eng</for-lang> <feature code="''"> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:morphology:option:quotation-mark-closing</IRI> <name>closing quotation mark</name> <desc>Examples: ' ''</desc> </feature> <feature code="--"> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Dash</IRI> <name>dash</name> <desc>Examples: --</desc> </feature> <feature code="$"> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Dollar_sign</IRI> <name>dollar</name> <desc>Examples: $ -$ --$ A$ C$ HK$ M$ NZ$ S$ U.S.$ US$</desc> </feature> <feature code="["> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:morphology:option:bracket-opening</IRI> <name>opening bracket</name> <desc>Examples: ( [ {</desc> </feature> <feature code="]"> ......... </feature> ......... </body> </TAN-mor>

section.para: The attribute context specifies under what conditions a particular <assert> or <report> will be tested. When an <m> in a dependent TAN-LM file is validated, if it contains the codes for the features in question, the other conditions of the <assert> or <report> will be checked.

caution.para: @feature-test and @context must point to one or more feature @codes or @xml:ids a space or +

section.para: The attribute feature-qty-test specifies a sequence of integers (e.g., 2-4). If the quantity of features in an <m> matches a number from that sequence, the condition is true, and false otherwise. If the keyword 'last' or 'max' is used, the number of features will be adopted as the ceiling.

This test is useful for non-category based languages to put a limit on the number of features that can be declared in an <m>. It is one of four tests for determining the truth value that will determin whether a <report> or <assert> will be acted upon.

caution.para: Sequences may not include values less than 1.
Sequences may not include values greater than the maximum allowed.
Sequences may not include ranges that go from a larger value to a smaller, e.g., 4 - 2.

section.para: The attribute feature-test specifies one or more features separated by spaces or the padded + (a plus sign with surrounding spaces). A plain space is treated as meaning "or" and the padded + as meaning "and." If there is at least one match between the list and the value of the codes in an <m> then condition will be treated as true. The padded plus sign specifies that all the items need to be found in the <m>.

For example, feature-test="A B + C D + E" means that the condition will be true for a given <m> only if it has A or B and C or D and E. This test is one of four tests for determining the truth value that will trigger the message in a <report> or <assert>

caution.para: @feature-test and @context must point to one or more feature @codes or @xml:ids a space or +

section.para: The attribute matches-m takes a regular expression. If an <m> matches the pattern, then the condition will be true.
One of four tests for determining the truth value that will trigger the message in a <report> or <assert>

caution.para: Attributes that take a regular expression must use escape sequences recognized by XML schema or TAN escape extensions (\k{}). See http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#regexs for details.

section.para: The attribute matches-tok takes a regular expression. When validating a given <m>, a test will be made against each companion <tok> (i.e., those <toks> that have the same ancestral <ana>). The condition will be treated as true only if there is a match with the resolved value of every such <tok>, and false if there is any nonmatch.
One of four tests for determining the truth value that will trigger the message in a <report> or <assert>

caution.para: Attributes that take a regular expression must use escape sequences recognized by XML schema or TAN escape extensions (\k{}). See http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#regexs for details.

section.title: TAN-rdf elements, attributes, and patterns summarized

section.para: The element modal contains an IRI + name pattern identifying a modal that qualifies an assertion.
The element person contains an IRI + name pattern identifying a person. This element is very similar to <agent>, but does not imply that the person had anything to do with the data in the TAN file.
Although person implies a single individual, this element may be applied to corporate entities, or natural groups of more than one person.
The element place contains an IRI + name pattern identifying a spatial location, usually somewhere on earth
The element TAN-rdf specifies that the TAN file makes assertions subject a conceptual work. Root element.

important.para: Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.Every validated TAN file will include the following message at its root.

section.para: The element unit contains an IRI + name pattern identifying a unit type (e.g., millimeters, seconds, Euros), to be used in conjunction with <object> to specify the meaning of a value
The element verb contains an IRI + name pattern identifying a property, relationship, action, or something else that is used to say something about something.

The preferred term "verb" is equivalent to RDF "predicate." The latter term is avoided as being misleading -- most who use TAN will understand "predicate," grammatically speaking, to refer to everything in a sentence that is not the subject,
The attribute adverb names a <modal> that qualifies the claim.
The attribute claimant points to an <agent> or <person> who makes a claim. @claimant within <body> indicates the default persons to be credited or blamed for an assertion.

Claimants are not to be confused with the editor of a TAN file. If an editor X writes a TAN-rdf file that says that person Y makes such-and-such a claim, then the implication is that X claims that Y claims that....

The attribute object points to one or more ID refs of entities defined in <head> that serve as the grammatical object of a claim. For example, if you wish to say that work A is a commentary on work B, then the object would have the ID ref for work B. If you wish to make more complex assertions, use <object>
The attribute object-datatype specifies the type of data that the object must take. Use this attribute if and only if the object is not an entity defined by the
The attribute object-lexical-constraint specifies a regular expression that constrains the value of any <object>

The attribute subject points to one or more ID refs of entities defined in <head> that serve as the grammatical subject of a claim. @subject within <body> indicates the default subject(s) for <claim>s.
The attribute units points to the ID ref of a <unit>, defining the type of units.

The attribute verb The preferred term "verb" is equivalent to RDF "predicate." The latter term is avoided as being misleading -- most who use TAN will understand "predicate," grammatically speaking, to refer to everything in a sentence that is not the subject,
The attribute where restricts the <claim> to a specific <place>
TAN-A-div: alignments may take either an id with no supplementary variables or else no id and optional variables indicating strength, exclusivity, distribution, and auto-alignment
TAN-A-tok: alignments may claim bitext relations and reuse type
TAN-A-div: alignments must contain either one or more div-refs or a list of IDREFS to other alignments
TAN-A-tok: alignments must contain one or more toks
TAN-A-div: alignments suppres @cert in <tok> (used only to split leaf divs)
TAN-A-div: no levels of certainty are allowed in TAN-A-div files; substitute is strength-claim
TAN-A-div: TAN-A-div files may not point to individual characters/glyphs
TAN-class-1: Class 1 files must declare a single work, perhaps one version, one or more divisions, one or more recommended tokenizations, perhaps one filter, and perhaps one
TAN-class-2: Reserved for declarations common to all class 2 files
TAN-class-3: Reserved for declarations common to all class 3 files
TAN-core: Reserved for any declarations that are shared across classes
TAN-class-1: Replacements that have been made to an XML source file.
TAN-A-tok: all declarations must have ids
TAN-key: all declarations must have ids
TAN-mor: no declarations may have ids
TAN-rdf: all declarations must have ids
section.synopsis: Formal Definition [TAN-A-tok] @xml:id OR [TAN-key] @xml:id OR [TAN-mor] {empty} OR [TAN-rdf] @xml:id OR [TAN-core] {empty}

section.para: TAN-core: Empty declaration element. See other TAN schemas for redefinitions appropriate to a particular type of TAN file.
TAN-class-1: Reserved for declarations specific to individual types of class 1 files
TAN-class-2: Reserved for declarations specific to individual types of class 2 files
TAN-mor: every TAN-R-mor file has one or more src-lang and feature elements
TAN-class-3: Reserved for declarations specific to individual types of class 3 files
TAN-core: decl-non-core to be filled out by each TAN-class-X.rnc file
section.synopsis: Formal Definition [TAN-key] OR [TAN-rdf] (<work>* & <place>* & <verb>+ & <unit>* & <person>* & <modal>* & <version>*) OR [TAN-class-1] ( (<work> & <version>? & <div-type>+ & <token-definition>* & <filter>?) & ) OR [TAN-class-2] ( (<token-definition>*<token-definition>* & <suppress-div-types>* & <rename-div-ns>*) & <topic>* (<bitext-relation>+ & <reuse-type>++ & <group-type>**)) OR [TAN-class-3] ( & ) OR [TAN-core] {empty}

section.para: TAN-class-2: Reserved for modification in different types of Class 2 files, to specify how many suppress-div-type declarations are allowed.
TAN-A-div: TAN-A-div files do not require a tokenization choice within a filter (choice enforced by Schematron)

TAN-class-2: Reserved for modification in different types of Class 2 files, to specify how many tokenization declarations are allowed. Class 2 files that do not require tokenization (i.e., TAN-A-div) may include <token-definition> only if the file uses elements (e.g., <split-leaf-div-at>) that assume tokenization.
TAN-core: String that specifies a range of divs using the div-ref pattern joined by a hyphen or a comma.
TAN-core: Editorial stamp: who created or edited the enclosed data and when.
TAN-core: Reference to an external digital entity that is not a TAN file
TAN-core: Reference to an external digital entity that is a TAN file; unlike other types, the keyword-ref option much be turned on and off for specific elements (e.g., not advisable for <inclusion>)
TAN-core: Reference to self as digital entity (i.e., TAN file)
TAN-core: Reference to an external non-digital entity (e.g., agents, roles, works, topics)
TAN-mor: TAN-R-mor files declare the morphological features that are allowed for a given language
TAN-class-2: Option to include an internal id. Not needed in TAN-LM files.

section.synopsis: Formal Definition [TAN-A-tok] <align> OR [TAN-key] <item> OR [TAN-rdf] <claim>+ OR [TAN-T] <div> OR [TAN-core] {empty}

section.para: TAN-key: No sense in having keywords refer by shorthand to other keywords
TAN-core: Acceptable values of @n, used by class 1 and class 2 files

section.synopsis: Formal Definition [TAN-A-tok] @bitext-relation,@reuse-type OR [TAN-key] @affects-element? OR [TAN-rdf] @claimant,@subject OR [TAN-T] @xml:lang OR [TAN-core] {empty}

section.para: TAN-class-2: Pointer (link) to a div in a TAN-T(EI) file
TAN-core: specifies whether the creation and editing of the data is still in progress. Default value is true.
TAN-class-2: Reference option allows TAN-LM files to point to languages as a whole in lieu of specific sources
TAN-core: String that specifies a range of tokens: digits or "last(-digit)?" joined by space-delimited hyphens or vertical lines (pipe character)
TAN-A-div: TAN-A-div sources must be named
TAN-A-tok: TAN-A-tok sources must be named
TAN-core: Parameter to indicate whether <source> should be allowed to take xml:id (forbidden for TAN files with only one source; mandated otherwise)
TAN-A-div: TAN-A-div files must have one or more sources
TAN-A-tok: TAN-A-tok files take exactly two sources
TAN-LM: TAN-LM files point only to one source
TAN-class-3: Class 3 files allow zero or many sources
section.synopsis: Formal Definition [TAN-A-div] <source>+ OR [TAN-A-tok] <source>,<source> OR [TAN-key] {empty} OR [TAN-LM] <source> OR [TAN-rdf] <source>* OR [TAN-class-3] <source>* OR [TAN-core] <source>

section.para: TAN-class-2: All sources are TAN files, so no source rights should be declared--they're already stated
TAN-A-div: This statement also does away with groups in TAN-A-div files
TAN-mor: TAN-R-mor body consists of zero or more assert, report, category, or options
TAN-mor: Test pattern attributes for determining whether to return the message provided by text.
TAN-core: Tag URN, mandatory pattern for the IRI name of every TAN file
TAN-rdf: points to one or more <verb>s that serve to assert something of the @subject.
